newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Hillary Clinton says S.Africans 'too busy to hate'.
newsitem.headline: Hillary Clinton says S.Africans 'too busy to hate'.

text.p: U.S. First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday praised South Africa's spirit of reconciliation in the post-apartheid period, saying the country is "too busy to hate".
President Bill Clinton's wife, in an appearance at the University of Cape Town, also predicted that the United States would elect a woman president within the next 20 years.

Speaking 31 years after U.S. Senator Robert Kennedy delivered a landmark address in South Africa on racial inequality, Mrs Clinton said Americans found inspiration in the work going on in the country to put the past behind it.

"We have an old saying in America that idle hands are the devil's work. From what I have seen in just a few short days, the devil will have no help here. South Africa is a country that is too busy to hate," she said.
She was to join President Nelson Mandela later on Thursday on a tour of Robben Island where he spent 18 of his 27 years as a political prisoner.
In a question-and-answer session, Mrs Clinton was asked whether she believed the United States would soon elect a woman as president.
She produced chuckles among the audience of students and representatives of women's groups when she replied: "I have thought a lot about this."
She said it was difficult in the United States to overcome preconceived notions and stereotypes about political leaders, and this made it hard for a woman to rise to the highest level of government.
"Having said that, I do hope and believe that sometime within the next 20 years we will have a woman president," she said.
She said it was possible some women might run in presidential elections in the year 2000, adding there were many well-qualified women who could undertake such a campaign.
In her address, she also hailed a trend towards democracy in Africa, mentioning Uganda, Eritrea and Mozambique.
"Yet nowhere has the triumph of the human spirit -- the power of love to conquer hate -- been greater than in South Africa," she said.
"Here the spirit of reconciliation has enabled a nation of diverse peoples to overcome 40 stubborn and violent years of apartheid and begin the difficult journey to democracy."
The success of democracy in South Africa would not depend solely on free elections, an open market, government policies nor foreign investment, she said.
"It will depend ultimately on the internalisation of democratic values in people's hearts, minds and everyday lives."

Mrs Clinton also announced that the United States was expanding support for a campaign to eradicate polio in Africa by the year 2000. She said the United States would commit a further $16 million to the effort.
